title: 107_s674
content: The Act is titled the "Access to Affordable Health Care Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Congress makes findings regarding the lack of health insurance among Americans, with a focus on small firms facing higher costs and being less likely to offer coverage to their employees. The Employee Benefit Research Institute found that in 1998, 27.4% of private sector workers in firms with fewer than 10 employees received health insurance from their employers, compared to 66.5% in firms with 1,000 or more employees. The purpose of the Act is to provide tax incentives to make health insurance more affordable for small businesses, encouraging them to offer coverage and discouraging dropping coverage due to rising costs. SEC. 45E. EMPLOYEE HEALTH INSURANCE EXPENSES. This section provides a tax credit for small businesses to make health insurance more affordable for employees. The tax credit for small businesses under section 45E allows for a percentage of qualified employee health insurance expenses to be claimed, with different percentages based on the number of employees. There are also dollar limitations per employee based on coverage type. The tax credit for small businesses under section 45E allows for a percentage of qualified employee health insurance expenses to be claimed, with different percentages based on the number of employees. Employers are considered as described in subsection (b) if they employed a certain number of employees in the preceding calendar years. The tax credit for small businesses under section 45E allows for a percentage of qualified employee health insurance expenses to be claimed based on the number of employees. Employers are considered based on the average number of employees expected to be employed in the current calendar year. Qualified employee health insurance expenses refer to amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage for qualified employees. The term 'health insurance coverage' under a salary reduction arrangement is considered for tax purposes. A 'qualified employee' is defined as an employee earning at least $5,000 annually. Certain employees, as defined by section 401(c)(1), are excluded from this definition. The term 'wages' is defined as per section 3121(a) without any dollar limitation. Rules similar to section 52 apply, and no double benefit is allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. Section 38(b) is amended to include the credit as part of the general business credit. The employee health insurance expenses credit is added as paragraph (14) under section 45E. No carryback of this credit is allowed before January 1, 2002. Clerical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45E. No carryback of this credit is allowed before January 1, 2002. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new deduction for health and long-term care insurance costs of individuals not participating in employer-subsidized health plans, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow a deduction for health and long-term care insurance costs for individuals without employer-subsidized health plans. The deduction is based on the amount paid during the taxable year for medical care insurance for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents, with the applicable percentage determined according to a specified table. For taxable years starting in 2002, the applicable percentage for health insurance deduction is 25%, increasing to 50% for 2005-2006, and 100% for 2007 onwards. Limitations apply if the taxpayer or spouse participates in an employer's health plan where 50% or more of the coverage cost is subsidized. Employer contributions to cafeteria plans, flexible spending arrangements, and medical savings accounts are treated as paid by the employer for health plans not described in the previous subparagraph. The text discusses how certain health plans should be treated based on specific criteria, separate from plans that include coverage for long-term care services. It also mentions the application of subparagraphs to different types of plans. The text exempts certain federal programs from subsection (a) coverage requirements for individuals already covered under specific medical care programs listed in titles XVIII, XIX, or XXI of the Social Security Act, chapter 55 of title 10, chapter 17 of title 38, chapter 89 of title 5, or the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The text outlines exceptions to coverage requirements for certain federal programs and specifies that qualified long-term care insurance contracts are exempt from certain deductions. Eligible long-term care premiums can be deducted under subsection (a), while ancillary coverage premiums are not eligible for deduction. Premiums paid for insurance covering accidents, disability, dental care, vision care, specified illnesses, or hospitalization are not considered for deduction. Special rules apply for coordination with deductions for self-employed health insurance costs and medical expenses. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary will prescribe regulations under section 213 for employers to report necessary information. A new deduction for health and long-term care insurance costs is added to the Internal Revenue Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Deduction for 100 percent of health insurance costs of self-employed individuals. Amendment to section 162(l) of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a deduction of 100 percent of medical insurance costs for employees under section 401(c)(1). Limitations on coverage apply to taxpayers participating in subsidized health plans maintained by certain employers. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
